author: Hannah Lowe
text: Errol drives me to Treasure Beach
swerving the dark country roads
I think about what you will be, your mix
white, black, Chinese, and your father’s
Scottish-Englishness. We cross the Black River
where they shipped cane sugar and molasses
upstream past a sign
for Lover’s Leap. The air stinks of sulphur
Errol drops me at a blue gate.
behind the house, the thin beach
of black sand, the water warm and gray
I am deep before I know it, groundless
the swell stops the sickness
under a crooked tree, perched on sea rocks
two fishermen in torn denims, smoking
I dry in the sun. They pass, turn, come close
they have rust afros, gold faces splashed with freckles
one ripped with muscle, one with eyes
like razors.
they say
title: High Yellow
